title: HW0 Q6
content: Problem Context:We need to make sure that everyone is comfortable with basic programming and also understands basic neural nets from their earlier ML course.
document:
Problem Context:

We need to make sure that everyone is comfortable with basic programming and also understands basic neural nets from their earlier ML course.

comments.content:
# what written in HW0 Q6DRIVE_PATH = f'/content/gdrive/My\ Drive/{REPO_NAME}/{HOMEWORK_DIR}'

# what actually works for me
DRIVE_PATH = f'/content/gdrive/My Drive/{REPO_NAME}/{HOMEWORK_DIR}'
i think there might be a typo '\' for shell but not worked for pythonI'm just checking to make sure my understanding is correct and to confirm if this is a small typo in the instructions.Thank you in advance!

"affine_forward" is not defined
when I try to run the test script, seems like the script doesn't naturally find the function from the files, do we need an explicit import statement? If yes, could you give an example of how it looks like in this case?

comments.content:
Had exactly the same issue! Adding this to the top of the cell helped:
import deeplearning.layers
from importlib import reloadreload(deeplearning.layers)
comments.document:
Had exactly the same issue! Adding this to the top of the cell helped:


import deeplearning.layers
from importlib import reload
reload(deeplearning.layers)

comments.content:
For the two-layer network, I flag these checks once in a while:
assert W1_std < std / 10, 'First layer weights do not seem right'
assert np.all(b1 == 0), 'First layer biases do not seem right'
assert W2_std < std / 10, 'Second layer weights do not seem right'
assert np.all(b2 == 0), 'Second layer biases do not seem right'
I'm assuming this isn't an issue due to the nature of variance, however I'm not entirely sure this is correct behavior. Is this something I should look into more?
comments.document:

assert np.all(b2 == 0), 'Second layer biases do not seem right'


I'm assuming this isn't an issue due to the nature of variance, however I'm not entirely sure this is correct behavior. Is this something I should look into more?

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>do we only need to include the code in our submission for this q or also derivations for backward passes? also just to clarify, we are only supposed to submit the Jupyter notebook pdf and not the our code in layers.py and the network python file?</paragraph></document>
comments.document: do we only need to include the code in our submission for this q or also derivations for backward passes? also just to clarify, we are only supposed to submit the Jupyter notebook pdf and not the our code in layers.py and the network python file?

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>As per the homework spec, you just need to upload the notebook. I'd assume the other files aren't necessary.</paragraph></document>
comments.document: As per the homework spec, you just need to upload the notebook. I'd assume the other files aren't necessary.

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>When I try to download my notebook as a pdf, the graphs are erased. Please advise.</paragraph></document>
comments.document: When I try to download my notebook as a pdf, the graphs are erased. Please advise.

comments.content: <document version="1.0"><paragraph>If you’re doing it locally using vscode, the console should give you an error and tell you to install a package (likely “imageio”) for images to save.</paragraph><paragraph>If you’re doing it on Google Collab, I’d suggest adding “imageio” to your list of imports.</paragraph></document>
comments.document:
If you’re doing it locally using vscode, the console should give you an error and tell you to install a package (likely “imageio”) for images to save.

If you’re doing it on Google Collab, I’d suggest adding “imageio” to your list of imports.

comments.content:
i try exporting the notebook as pdf via adding a line:
!jupyter nbconvert --to html "Untitled.ipynb"
... but all my graphs get erased. I can just print the notebook, but it looks kind of ugly. Is there a preferred way to convert jupyter notebook to pdf?
comments.document:
i try exporting the notebook as pdf via adding a line:

!jupyter nbconvert --to html "Untitled.ipynb"


... but all my graphs get erased. I can just print the notebook, but it looks kind of ugly. Is there a preferred way to convert jupyter notebook to pdf?

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>If you're vscode and have Jupyter extension, there's an export button on the top-navigation bar. It works well for me.</paragraph><paragraph/></document>
comments.document: If you're vscode and have Jupyter extension, there's an export button on the top-navigation bar. It works well for me.
